messages.text: I am having trouble with a `SignatureDoesNotMatch` error when calling `S3.get_object`. With some keys, everything works as expected. However, with a key containing this substring, I get the error: `0 2016-12-28T113155+0100 4.1.avi`. Maybe it has something to do with the characters in that key?

messages.text: I think it is the `+` character. I copied the S3 object to a new key without any `+` in the key and the error is gone. This won't work as a workaround, though, so I would like to see if we can debug/fix the way the signature.

messages.text: Ah, I think I figured it out. `HTTP.escapeuri` is doing the right thing and escaping the _whole_ URI, including any forward slashes in the key. My URIs are really of the form `a/b/c.avi`, so I need to split on `/`, map the parts using `HTTP.escapeuri` and the join with `/`.

```julia> cp(source, destination)

"""
HTTP/1.1 403 Forbidden
x-amz-request-id: 345752ABEB0E778D
x-amz-id-2: r26YRQX+HJvRjMYjFqancyTWeDCjCScIUbCvnWO41BOVERzEIuPvATRn3t8mXV9Kx2CIvEFMYkk=
Content-Type: application/xml
Transfer-Encoding: chunked
Date: Mon, 14 Dec 2020 17:06:20 GMT
Server: AmazonS3

"""))

messages.text: Hi everyone, so what is the recommended julia package to use for AWS? Because <https://github.com/JuliaCloud/AWS.jl> says it replaces <https://github.com/JuliaCloud/AWSCore.jl>, but at the same time AWSCore seems to have all/a lot of documentation whereas I am struggling to figure out how to even find which functions I can call in AWS.jl without having to dive into source code essentially
